body:
I think we could be cleaner / more polite if we supported running `sudo make uninstall` at the top level.
IMO, not providing uninstall is the main reason why some users don't want to install from source to see if their problems reproduce that way.

CMake already creates an install manifest, and supporting this is only a couple of code snippets away (see http://www.cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#Can_I_do_.22make_uninstall.22_with_CMake.3F).

I think I could do it, but prefer leaving it to those who better know our current CMake setup.
@jszakmeister @fwalch Want to take the task?

comment_data.body:
> IMO, not providing uninstall is the main reason why some users don't want to install from source to see if their problems reproduce that way.

I'm not sure I agree with that assertion.  I think people avoid it because they just haven't done it before, and don't know how to get all the right pieces into place.  I think we've gone a long way towards making that easier.  Combined with it being so easy to shove the installed neovim under it's own prefix, I'm not sure it's necessary.

Note that the paradigm given in the FAQ doesn't clean up the file tree--it leaves empty directories lying around--and it won't include generated files (like the helptags).

Well, I think we're saying the same thing, more or less. They haven't done it before, so they fear it, so they don't want to do it unless they have a clean way of undoing it.

In any case, it this supposes a lot of work, then I understand there are more important things to do now. I just don't grok cmake, so I don't know, and because of that FAQ, I thought it was an easy thing.

I think we should reconsider this. We're having a lot of false issue reports because of stale python_setup.vim and related config hanging around in user installations. We'll probably get more of those when we publish the newsletter. And there will be more breaking changes like this in future. I think we should have a way to nuke down an existing installation, so that make install really installs a fresh version.

I have a snippet in my `.zprofile` that greatly helps managing home installations. I use it to install almost every software that is not part of my distro's package manager(I have about 20 packages installed there at this time):

``` sh
prefixes_dir="$HOME/.user-prefixes"
if [[ -d $prefixes_dir ]]; then
    for dir in "$prefixes_dir"/*; do
        dir=${dir:A}
        if [[ -d "$dir/bin" ]]; then
            PATH="$dir/bin:$PATH"
        fi
        if [[ -d "$dir/share/man" ]]; then
            MANPATH="$dir/share/man:$MANPATH"
        fi
        if [[ -d "$dir/lib" ]]; then
            LD_LIBRARY_PATH="$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:$dir/lib"
        fi
        if [[ -d "$dir/lib/pkgconfig" ]]; then
            PKG_CONFIG_PATH="$dir/lib/pkgconfig:$PKG_CONFIG_PATH"
        fi
    done
fi
unset dir prefixes_dir
export PATH MANPATH LD_LIBRARY_PATH PKG_CONFIG_PATH
```

This will adjust `PATH`, `MANPATH`, `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` and  `PKG_CONFIG_PATH` based on `~/.user-prefixes` subdirectories. In a few words, this allows me to install things in `~/.user-prefixes` that can easily be removed. This is how I install nvim:

```
make CMAKE_EXTRA_FLAGS='-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$HOME/.user-prefixes/nvim'
```

and this is how I uninstall it:

```
rm -rf ~/.user-prefixes/nvim
```

We could also try if we can do something for distro packages to get updated more often, then people don't have to install manually and we won't have this problem.

Eliseo Martínez notifications@github.com wrote:

> I think we should reconsider this. We're having a lot of false issue reports because of stale python_setup.vim and related config hanging around in user installations. We'll probably get more of those when we publish the newsletter. And there will be more breaking changes like this in future. I think we should have a way to nuke down an existing installation, so that make install really installs a fresh version.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.￼

> IMO, not providing uninstall is the main reason why some users don't want to install from source to see if their problems reproduce that way.

I agree with that and I am sorry to say that I do that. I had once installed `neovim` using `sudo make install` and had no idea how to do something equavalent to `sudo make uninstall`. For now, I will just do `make` in **Neovim**.
Added an [Uninstall](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Installing-Neovim#uninstall-a-source-build) section to the wiki.
@justinmk Your link does not contain an Uninstall section (anymore).

Someone removed it ><

Partially restored it for now: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Installing-Neovim#uninstall

I am very annoyed that it was removed...

Maybe we could provide a real 'uninstall' target from CMake.

It's documented in the [CMake FAQ](https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#Can_I_do_.22make_uninstall.22_with_CMake.3F)

I can write a PR if you like

@dmerejkowsky Sure, but rather than using `install_manifest.txt` as the authority I suggest only doing the equivalent of these steps:

```
rm $CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/bin/nvim
rm -r $CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX/share/nvim/
```

@justinmk : Why?

Doing that would leave the `nvim.mo` files in `share/locale` and  the man pages in `share/man`.

Using the `install_manifest.txt` is more DRY: we won't have to fix the `uninstall` target if we start installing stuff in other directories.

I don't understand why you do not like using `install_manifest.txt` as the authority, but maybe there's something I'm missing here.
I'm pretty sure that technique will also leave things on the file system.  Namely, some of the directory structure with empty directories left behind. :-(
Ah you're right. Maybe we can still write something clever. Let me think about it

Any word on adding an uninstall option? The wiki entry's suggestion of:

```bash
sudo rm /usr/local/bin/nvim
sudo rm -r /usr/local/share/nvim/
```

doesn't remove man pages, desktop files and so on.

> doesn't remove man pages, desktop files and so on.

But do we install those?

Yup. Running `sudo make install` command gives the following output (ignoring `/usr/local/share/nvim` and `/usr/local/bin/nvim`):

```bash
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/share/man/man1/nvim.1
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/share/locale/ja.euc-jp/LC_MESSAGES/nvim.mo
-- Up-to-date: /usr/local/share/locale/cs.cp1250/LC_MESSAGES/nvim.mo
```

Full output: [neovim_install_output.txt](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/files/2945472/neovim_install_output.txt)

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: Add uninstall support.
